title: Years Of Study And Suffering In Vienna

slides.title: Vienna: A Fateful Chapter
content: Arrived in Vienna armed with drawing portfolio, confident in art school entrance exam success.
Dualism of his aptitude for drawing and painting began to dawn during the entrance exam process.
Disappointed at initial rejection from general painting school at the Academy of Fine Arts.
Rector suggested aptitude for architectural design, which was a totally new thought for young Adolf.
slides.script: Let's begin by looking at Hitler's arrival in Vienna. This city would play a massive role in shaping his worldview. He arrived brimming with confidence, ready to ace the entrance exams to the Academy of Fine Arts. He thought his drawing skills were top-notch. The rejection from the general painting school was not expected. The Academy Rector actually suggested that Adolf had a knack for architectural design.

slides.title: Dreams Deferred
content: Realized he should pursue architecture, but lacked required technical school certificate, which needed a Leaving Certificate.
Mother's death compounded the situation, creating financial and emotional stress.
Obstacles strengthened his will to strive through and follow his father's path of upward mobility.
Harsh living conditions and poverty ultimately helped him understand a different world.
slides.script: The rejection forced him to reconsider his path. The Rector noted architecture is his best option. This presented another problem: He lacked the academic qualifications for architecture school. This setback, along with his mother's death, led to years of poverty and hardship in Vienna. But this era taught him valuable lessons of hard work, resilience and the plight of lower classes.

slides.title: Poverty and Perspective
content: Five years of poverty as laborer and painter in Vienna. Hardship and struggle, accompanied by books.
Acquired knowledge shaped a view of life that became a bedrock of his later actions.
Developed the core of his Weltanschauung, shaping his future political trajectory and decision-making.
Circumstances revealed the difference between hollow appearances and the true nature of men.
slides.script: These were not easy years. Hitler experienced severe poverty, working as a laborer and a painter. Despite the hardships, he dedicated himself to self-education, reading extensively. During this time his worldview took shape, forming the foundation for his later political career. Through personal experience, he saw through superficial appearances to understand people's inner natures and their living conditions.

slides.title: Encountering Marxism
content: Vienna exposed Hitler to Marxism and Judaism for the first time.
Observed stark inequalities in Vienna, rich aristocracy versus impoverished workers, which fueled his inquiries.
Saw the exploitation of misery, learned about the cycle of poverty, unemployment and strike actions.
He witnessed men become instruments for selfish and destructive forces, the manipulation by unscrupulous people.
slides.script: Vienna also exposed him to Marxism, a political ideology that heavily shaped his actions in the future. He observed the vast inequalities of the city, a stark contrast between rich and poor. He saw the exploitation of misery, the cycle of poverty, and the manipulation of workers by unscrupulous people.

slides.title: Disillusionment With Social Democracy
content: Initially sympathetic to Social Democracy, due to promotion of universal suffrage that might hurt Austrian government.
Estranged by hostile attitude towards Germanism in Austria and alliance with Slav comrades.
Social Democratic theoretical literature sounds grand, but their daily press propagated human redemption in a brutal fashion.
The power of the media to twist the truth and slander opponents was revealed to Hitler.
slides.script: Initially, Hitler was sympathetic to Social Democracy and its focus on equality, as it might weaken the Austrian government. However, he grew alienated by the party's hostile attitude toward German identity and its alliance with Slavs. Discrepancies between the party's theoretical claims and the brutal reality of the Social Democratic press led to disenchantment.

slides.title: The Psychological Power of Marxism
content: Observed Marxism's effective use of intimidation against the bourgeoisie, and physical intimidation of individuals.
Understood the attraction of Marxism for the masses through its uncompromising and brutal dominance.
Came to believe a truthful teaching must be enforced with equal ruthlessness to prevail.
Concluded that the masses are drawn to strength and intolerance, rather than liberal choices.
slides.script: He recognized Marxism's effective use of psychological and physical intimidation. He understood the masses prefer ruthless force and brutality. These points led him to feel that a truthful teaching, such as what he envisioned, must be enforced with equal ruthlessness in order to prevail.

slides.title: Discovering the Jew
content: Discovered Jews held leadership positions in Social Democratic Party, changing his understanding.
Recognized that no newspaper connected with the Jews could be described as 'National'.
Argued that the Jewish leaders promoted an agenda against the wellbeing of the people.
His debates with Jews revealed their tactic of twisting arguments, escaping logic and evading precise statements.
slides.script: He also discovered Jews held leadership roles within the Social Democratic Party. This discovery solidified his anti-Semitic beliefs. According to Hitler, no newspapers that Jews were connected with were patriotic. His interactions with Jews revealed evasive argumentative tactics.

slides.title: Hatred and Conviction
content: His encounters with Jewish leaders solidified his love for his people.
Concluded it was futile to argue with Jews and felt hatred.
Saw two-fold method to improve conditions: social responsibility with ruthless removal of unreformable.
Concluded Social activity must eliminate economic & cultural life deficiencies and lead to degradation.
slides.script: This discovery solidified his anti-Semitic feelings and his connection to the German people. Hitler found it futile to argue with Jews and grew to hate them. He outlined his vision of how to improve conditions: establish social responsibility with ruthless removal of unreformable elements and eliminate deficiencies in economic and cultural life, which are the reasons for societal degradation.

slides.title: The People's Indifference?
content: Outraged when a tramp said it is all the same to him whether he be a German or not as long as he can get enough to live on.
Argues that a lack of national pride arose from meagre knowledge of the Fatherland.
Ignorance from poverty, plus cinema, newspapers and obscene books poison minds.
Concluded people are 'nationalized' by healthy social conditions and knowledge of the greatness of their country.
slides.script: He expressed outrage when a tramp said it did not matter what his nationality was as long as his needs were met. He argued a lack of national pride arose from ignorance of the greatness of the Fatherland. He also found that media poisoned the minds of citizens. He concluded that making people feel more ‘national’ required healthy social conditions and education about their own nation’s achievements and history.

slides.title: Trades Unions Reconsidered
content: Trades unions: Originally viewed as inseparable from Social Democracy and repudiated.
Later, distinguished between trades unions as defenders of employees and as political instruments of class struggle.
German stupidity made them lose out to Social Democrats, who promised economic rights.
Therefore, the trade-union became the chief political recruiting ground to swell the ranks of the Social Democratic Party.
slides.script: Initially, Hitler rejected trade unions. Later, he came to distinguish between unions as organizations to defend worker's rights and as tools for Marxist class struggle. The German elite's negligence led the workers to turn to Social Democrats, who are thus able to exploit economic rights through the unions.

slides.title: The State and the Individual
content: The parliamentary regime had no individual responsibility. No one was to be called to account.
Questions whether a man is a competent statesman if he cannot persuade the majority of a parliament.
Parliamentary system contradicts the aristocratic principle based on individual personality.
Mediocrity and cowardice are rampant; leading to rapid change in public positions.
slides.script: Hitler decried the parliamentary system, describing it as lacking in individual responsibility and rewarding mediocrity. It contradicted the aristocratic principle of individual leadership. He felt such a system led to rapid change in public positions with the people in those roles not really knowing what to do.

slides.title: Revolutionary Art and Politics
content: Revolutionary in politics and art. Attended theatre performances and was entranced by Wagnerian opera.
The death of his mother forced him to make life decisions, leave Realschule, and head to Vienna.
Set out to become 'something' but certainly not a civil servant; he had little to no education or preparation.
It was by his own sheer will and force that he made his way through society. He wanted to be an Architect.
slides.script: Hitler describes himself as precocious in politics and art. He attended the theatre and loved Wagnerian opera. His mother's death forced him to make choices, leave Realschule, and head to Vienna. Even without any education or preparation, he wanted to be an architect.

slides.title: Conclusions in Vienna
content: Developed his historical thinking in school, viewing history as a source for understanding contemporary events.
Decided Austria's dissolution was necessary for Germany's defense, dynastic patriotism vs. nationalism.
Profound love for home in German-Austria, intense hatred for Austrian state.
Vienna school hard, forced me to look at things which didn't please me.
slides.script: He states that the dissolution of the Austrian Empire was necessary for Germany’s defense, his nationalistic patriotism was more compelling than dynastic loyalty, and that the House of Habsburg was destined to bring misfortune to the German nation. He viewed Vienna school was hard, since it forced him to look at things which didn't please me.

slides.title: Providence
content: Thankful for this period of life, hardened him and saved him from emptiness of a life of ease.
Grateful for being thrown into misery and poverty, came to know the people for whom I was afterwards to fight.
In those times, his eyes opened to Marxism and Judaism, though he previously had little idea of their significance.
Looking back, considers the time as Providential:  ‘The Goddess of Fate' was hard, but it made him tough.
slides.script: Hitler is thankful for this period of life, which hardened him and saved him from emptiness. He is grateful for being thrown into misery and poverty, as it allowed him to know the people for whom he was fighting for. It also gave him the insight to know of the importance of fighting Marxism and Judaism. He views his life then as a product of Providence, and views the hardness of the era as 'The Goddess of Fate'.
